Monument of Marcella, (daughter) of Romanus, who came to rest (died) on the 7th (day) of (the) month Xanthikos, in (the) year 319. May the Lord Jesus give (her) rest. Amen. (She died at the age) of 38 years.

The inscription provides the date as the 7th day of the month Xanthikos in the year 319 according to the Era of the Province of Arabia, that is, March 28, 424 CE. The tombstone is one of about 700 discovered in Byzantine Zoora. The majority of the Greek tombstones from this location have been identified as Christian. Originally rectangular, the tombstone is broken in the upper and lower left corners, curved at the upper right corner, and chipped around its edges. The inscribed surface is smoothed except for its lower section. The engraved text is written in round script. The text is surrounded by a red painted frame on all sides except for the bottom. Centered above the text, an outlined cross is engraved with the letters alpha and omega flanking its lower half. A simple cross appears at the end of line nine. Below the text, a rope-like pattern appears where the lower side of the frame would be. Two schematically drawn figures appear below this pattern: a bird on the left and a fish on the right, both of which are facing to the right. The text contains both spelling and grammatical errors. In line four, a superfluous S sign appears after the preposition ἐν. A horizontal bar appears above the month day numeral in line five, the abbreviations of Κυρίος and Ἰησοῦς in line seven, and the age numeral in line nine. A horizontal stroke appears above the year numeral in line six. The personal name Μαρκέλλας is the Greek rendering of the Latin name Marcella. The patronymic ῾Ρωμανός was a popular geographical cognomen in the Roman Empire.
